caption.paragraph:
Fig. 39.
Olonia nobilis (Stål, 1863)
comb. nov. in nature, Lizard Island, Casuarina Beach , 1 Mar. 2016. A–B . Female on
Ipomoea pes-caprae
. C . Two females on
Ipomoea pes-caprae
. D . Habitat. Photographs by A. Hoggett.

subSubSection.paragraph: This species can be recognized by the following combination of characters:
(1) hind wings without orange marking ( Figs 41E , 43E )
(2) pro- and mesofemora and tibiae largely black-brown ( Figs 41A–D , 43A–D )
(6) rather small size: 6.5–7.5 mm

Females of
O. picea
are nearly impossible to separate from females of the sympatric
O. maura
and should be identified only if collected together with males.
The species epithet piceus (adjective, Latin) means ʻpiceousʼ, ʻbrownʼ. It refers to the general colour of the species.

materialsCitation.paragraph:
AUSTRALIA • 1 ♁ ; Queensland , Cairns ; [ 16°55′19″ S , 145°46′32″ E ]; “Cairns, Q., Austr. 8-1904”, “Allotype”, “
Olonia picea Kirk.
♁ 308”; here designated to provide a reference standard for the species; BPBM ( Fig. 40 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paralectotypes
AUSTRALIA • 1 ♀ ; “Cairns, Q., Austr. 7, 1904”, “Holotype”, “
Olonia picea Kirk.
♀ 308”; BPBM • 1 ♀; “Cairns, Q., Austr. 7, 1904”, “Paratype” (BPBM)
; 2 ♁♁, “Cairns, Q., Austr. 8-1904”, “♁”, “Paratype”; BPBM.

One of the two male paralectotypes is actually a male of
O. maura ( Fabricius, 1775 )
.

subSubSection.paragraph: MEASUREMENTS AND RATIOS. LT: ♁ (n = 6): 7.2 mm (6.8–7.4); ♀ (n = 1): 7.2 mm ; Ltg/BTg (♁) = 2.3.
to black, reaching metacoxae. Antennae black-brown; scape short, ring-shaped; pedicel subcylindrical, slightly narrowing towards apex.

subSubSection.paragraph: apicosutural angle. Costal and sutural margins subparallel; costal margin slightly sinuate; apical margin obliquely rounded.
ABDOMEN. Bright red with genital segments black-brown.

This species has been recorded from an area around Cairns in North Queensland ( Fig. 3 ), in the Einasleigh Upland Savanna and Queensland Tropical Rainforests bioregions. Specimens were collected in January, February, March, April, July, August and September. No host plant known.
